title: driver who left partner baby
story: NewsDriver who left partner and baby in wrecked car following police chase jailedLiam Swinfield jumped into a canal after crashing his Vauxhaul Corsa but realised he couldnt swim and begged to be pulled from the waterShareCommentsByMartin Naylor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsLiam Swinfield has been jailed for  months "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA dangerous driver left his injured one-year-old son and his partner in a smoking car after he flipped it on to its roof following a high-speed chase.Liam Swinfield collided with four other vehicles during his bid to escape pursuing cops through Long Eaton, Derby Crown Court heard.The -year-old, who was unlicensed and uninsured, mounted a pavement, took a roundabout the wrong way and then hit the last car, flipping his Vauxhall Corsa on to its roof, reports Derbyshire Live.Telling his partner that he had to go, he left her and their son in the upturned vehicle before jumping into a nearby canal. But realising he couldn’t swim, Swinfield then begged a police officer to pull him from the water. The officer in question was holding Swinfields baby at the time, having removed the child from the upturned vehicle.   Jailing him for  months, Recorder Simon King said: “This was as dangerous as it is possible to get without it resulting in death or serious injury not only to your partner and son but to other road users. “The horrible irony is that the two people who suffered the most serious injuries, although thankfully they were not too serious, were your partner and young son who you left abandoned in the car which you flipped. “The maximum sentence I can give you is two years and I am obliged to give you % credit for your guilty plea.   “Be assured thatthere was a more serious punishment available to me I would have no hesitation to handing it to you.” Sarah Slater, prosecuting, played CCTV footage of part of the chase to the court. It showed officers begin to follow Swinfield, in Nottingham Road, before he accelerates into Cleveland Avenue, reaching more than mph in a mph street.  Swinfield then speeds down Lansdown Grove, Florence Avenue, Norfolk Road, back on the Nottingham Road, Market Place and finally on to Tamworth Road where he collides with the final vehicle and ends up on the roof. Miss Slater said: “In a statement, his partner said she was asking him to stop and he was telling her it would be okay. “She said she remembers being in the car with it on the roof and with their child in a seat in the back. “She said he said to her ‘I have got to go’ and left her and the baby in the car which, by now, was smoking.” Miss Slater said the woman and baby were freed from the car and, as one of the officers was holding the baby, Swinfield was calling for help to get him out of the canal as he could not swim. He was arrested, charged and pleaded guilty to dangerous driving, failing to stop following an accident and to driving without insurance or a valid licence. The incident happened at .pm on Saturday, January , involved a Vauxhall Corsa and closed part of Tamworth Road, in Long Eaton. The partner and child were taken to the Queens Medical Centre following the crash which saw them both receive black eyes and bruising. Christopher Brewin, for Swinfield, said: “He does appreciate how serious this is and he’s ashamed of his conduct.” As well as the jail term, Recorder King handed Swinfield a two-year driving ban. In  Swinfield, of Marriott Avenue, Chilwell, Nottingham, was part of a gang of criminals who carried out a pound, “cash for crash” scam across Derbyshire.

title: meghan markle meets moroccos king
story: NewsMeghan Markle meets Moroccos king in final tour engagement with Prince HarryThe Duchess of Sussex stunned in a £, Carolina Herrera dress as she and Harry met Mohammed VI of Morocco at the monarchs residence in RabatShareCommentsByLaura ForsythRussell Myers:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsMeghan and Harry with the King of Moroccoand his son The Crown Prince of Morocco, Moulay Hassan"Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghan Markle wowed in a custom designer gown as she met Moroccos king in her final tour engagement with Prince Harry . And plans for the Duke and Duchess of Sussex to make atrip to Morocco appear to be in the offing after Harry said they would come back and keep it very quiet. The couple ended their three-day tour by spending around an hour with Moroccos King Mohammed VI at his private residence surrounded by his immediate family. The duchess made her third outfit change of the day into a stunning pound, Carolina Herrera dress.  Meghan, who is around seven months pregnant, wore the flowing blue gown from Herreras AW collection at the monarchs residence in Rabat on Monday evening. With a crew neck, flared short sleeves and a fitted waistline, the dress is by a designer favoured by Queen Letizia of Spain. The King granted an audience to Harry and Meghan in his private home, a s Arabic-style country mansion set in a lush garden of ferns and bamboo trees in the capital Rabat.   But it was more like a get together with friends with the -year-old Crown Prince Moulay Hassan greeting the couple outside the door after they arrived in the Kings vintage Mercedes  SEL, loaned to the couple during their stay. The head of state was all smiles in the doorway and Harry and Meghan both complimented his home which featured an ornate internal courtyard behind the monarch, richly decorated with Arabic designs.   There was one formality with Harry presenting a private message from his grandmother the Queen in a large envelope. In a side room the royal party sat down with the Crown Prince joining Meghan on a sofa, Harry and the King nearby on another, and on a third sofa the monarchs sisters Princesses Meryem and Hasna and his brother Prince Moulay Rachid.  Missing was the Kings we Princess Lalla Salma who has been the subject of much speculation after disappearing from public le more than a year ago - with rumours circulating she may be living abroad. Harry described how he had an invitation from an unknown inidual to stay on after their tour ended: He was very keen on getting us down there two days after this trip, unfortunately we have commitments to get back to.  He also said to the King he would not be able to take up your fantastic invitation. But he added: Next time we will schedule it properly. We will keep it very quiet from everybody out there. Earlier in the day, the pregnant Duchess, , and the Duke of Sussex learned how the countrys love of horses is being used to help children with disabilities at an equestrian club in Rabat.  The royal couple then moved on to watch underprivileged children make a dish from the Grenfell cookbook championed by Meghan. They were pictured full of smiles as they tasted some of the delicious recipes. Meghan and Harry then took a tour around the beautul Andalusian Gardens in Moroccos capital.  The couple earlier learned about the country’s developing programme of equine therapy for children with special needs, funded by King Mohammed. Arriving at the Royal Equestrian Club Dar Essalam, the country’s main equestrian venue, they were introduced to Louis Broski from Holland, the founder of the Centre Social Kariat in Sale, near Rabat. It says  per cent of sewer blockages are avoidable, adding: “Avoidable blockages caused by unflushables lead to sewer flooding of homes and environmental pollution, which is distressing, costly to put right, and potentially devastating for wildle and our local waterways and seas.” The company also advised people to “only flush the three ‘Ps’ – pee,paper and poo”.

story: NewsNorth Koreas Kim Jong Un arrives in Vietnam for second summit with TrumpThe latest get together comes eight months after their historic first meeting in Singapore - but the vague agreement made a the time has had little in the way of concrete resultsShareCommentsByKhanh VuSam Rkaina:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video kim-jong-un-arrives-vietnam-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNorth Korean leader Kim Jong Un has arrived in Vietnam for a summit with Donald Trump. The two leaders will try to reach an agreement on a Norths Korean pledge to give up its nuclear weapons programme Trump is due to arrive in the Vietnamese capital, Hanoi, later on Tuesday. They will meet the next day for a brief one-on-one conversation, followed by a social dinner, at which they will each be accompanied by two guests and interpreters. White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders told reporters on Air Force One that would be followed by more meetings between the two leaders on Thursday.   Their talks come eight months after their historic summit in Singapore, the first between a sitting US president and a North Korean leader. While there is no real expectation that the second meeting will bring a final deal on ridding North Korea of nuclear weapons that threaten the US, there are some hopes it could lead to a declaration that the - Korean War is at last formally over. But the United States would expect signicant movement by Kim towards denuclearisation in .  In Singapore, Kim pledged to work toward complete denuclearisation of the Korean peninsula, but the vague agreement struck there has produced few concrete results. US Democratic senators and security officials have warned Trump against cutting a deal that would do little to curb North Koreas nuclear ambitions. Kim, who travelled from the North Korean capital by train, arrived at the station in the Vietnamese town of Dong Dang after crossing over the border from China. Vietnamese officials were on hand to receive him at the station with a red-carpet including a guard of honour and North Korean and Vietnamese flags flying.   Kim was seen leaving the train in Dong Dang and getting into a Mercedes Benz vehicle for the  mile journey to the capital, Hanoi, by car. He waved from the car before setting off to young people lining the street waving Vietnamese and North Korean flags. About a dozen body guards ran along side his car as he set off. Both Kim and Trump are also due to hold separate talks with Vietnamese leaders. US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo also arrived in Hanoi, on Tuesday, a reporter travelling with him said.  Pompeo has been Trumps top envoy in his efforts to improve ties with the reclusive North and has made several trips to Pyongyang to negotiate steps towards ending its nuclear programme. Trump told reporters he and Kim would have a very tremendous summit. Tweeting on Monday, he stressed the benefits to North Koreait gave up its nuclear weapons. With complete Denuclearization, North Korea will rapidly become an Economic Powerhouse. Without it, just more of the same. Chairman Kim will make a wise decision! Trump said. In a speech on Sunday night, Trump, however, appeared to play down any hope of a major breakthrough at the Hanoi summit, saying he would be happy as long as North Korea maintained its pause on weapons testing.  Im not in a rush. I dont want to rush anybody, he said. I just dont want testing. As long as theres no testing, were happy. North Korea conducted its last nuclear test in September  and last tested an intercontinental ballistic missile in November . A South Korean presidential spokesman told reporters in Seoul on Monday that the two sides might be able to agree to a formal end of the Korean War, which ended in an armistice not a peace treaty, a move North Korea has long sought. While a formal peace treaty may be a long way off, the two sides have discussed the possibility of a political declaration stating that the war over. The possibility is there, the South Korean spokesman, Kim Eui-kyeom told a briefing.

title: dundee boss mcintyre ready to cross swords with new hibs gaffer heckingbottom
story: Jim McIntyre and Paul Heckingbottom will cross swords for the first time in their managerial careers when Dundee and Hibs clash at Dens tonight.However, while Jim admits to knowing little of his opposite number, his knowledge of the team he’ll be putting out means he’s not expecting too many tactical surprises.Hibs appointed Heckingbottom as the successor to Neil Lennon last week and he kicked off his time in Scotland with an Easter Road win over Hamilton Accies.While, in time, the Dee boss knows his opposite number will put his own stamp on the Hibees, right now he’s not expecting too many drastic tactical changes from the way they lined up under Lennon.“I don’t know him but he got off to a good start and Hibs have good players. title: dundee charity help for kids teams up with luxury resort forbes of kingennie
story: Children’s charity Help for Kids is celebrating after a local business decided to name it as its charity of the year.Forbes of Kingennie Resort will work with the young persons’ charity, inviting children from dficult backgrounds to the resort and hosting fundraising events throughout the year.The partner-ship is the first of many the charity hopes to form with Tayside firms, which will allow it to carry on helping disadvantaged children and teenagers in and around Dundee and Perth.Help for Kids aims to raise funds at Forbes events with bucket collections but also hopes members of staff at the Angus resort will take part in mass participation events such as marathons, mountain climbs and the Kiltwalk.However, the charity has said it’s equally important to it that Forbes has been willing to help local young people by inviting them to visit and experience the facilities for the first time.The holiday resort will welcome groups of young people aged - who study in off-site education schools.Once there, the kids will take part in a range of activities, like fishing and golf. title: dundee people youngsters go down to the woods to explore
story: If you go down to the woods today you are sure of a big surprise, in the shape of youngsters from Ninewells Nursery.The pre-school children were once again out and about in the community and having a great time while also learning lots of new things.The little ones headed out to take part in a nature walk around the grounds of Ninewells Hospital which is right next to the nursery building. vw, px"   vw, px"  Nursery manager Adelle Taylor said: “All of the kids had a great time exploring the nature in the grounds.“They collected leaves and sticks and also discovered some new plants.“While on the walk the children came across lots of snowdrops which they were all very interested in and they loved sitting together on a fallen tree trunk.“Kids at the nursery go to the woods and to nature trails regularly and learn all about woodland and wildle while they are there.“Not only are the discovering new things that they have never seen before but they love looking at all the plants and trees together.”

title: dundee railway station units remain empty because of paying living wage
story: Units at Dundee’s new railway station entrance may still be sitting empty six months after it opened because occupants have been ordered to pay a living wage, it has been suggested.Estate agents Ryden were put in charge of finding tenants for the units inside the new station entrance, which opened last July.However, following an initial flurry of interest in the units – including an offer on the retail block – the facilities are still to find occupants.Neither unit is currently under offer, according to listings on Ryden’s website.This is despite both being prepared by builders for “immediate occupation” to make them lucrative to would-be occupants.It has been suggested in some circles that Dundee City Council’s insistence on occupants of the city’s new Waterfront development paying a “living wage” has put firms off.The council pays its staff wages that align with the Living Wage Foundation’s benchmark.In Scotland, this is currently £ an hour, higher than the National Living Wage of £. that is set for adults over  by the UK Government. vw, px"  One business source told the Tele: “You would have thought the station would have opened with the units occupied.“I think part of the issue is the living wage. If, for example, a big company didn’t pay the living wage but wanted to move into Dundee, it would have to agree to pay it.“That could make things dficult for them as it would set a precedent for their stores where in the UK.”Despite the apparent lack of interest, “discussions with the council about prospective tenants” are ongoing, according to one partner in the estate agency.The Tele understands supermarket chain Sainsbury’s had considered the station’s retail unit, but has opted to open its first city centre “Local” shop on Perth Road.A number of other supermarkets and coffee shop firms approached for comment by the Tele say they have no plans for the units.Bill Marley, a partner with Ryden, said at the time of the station’s opening that the agents were working “closely” with Dundee City Council to market the units.Ryden is also responsible for marketing the full range of units across the £ billion Waterfront project.Dundee City Council was approached for comment ahead of going to press.

title: dundee swimmers splash to raise cash for charity

title: global charity plans revamp and to do more near its dundee base
story: A Dundee charity that carries out work around the globe has unveiled plans to renovate its building – and do more closer to home.Signpost International will rebrand its Whitfield HQ as the Centre for Global Learning as it looks to foster better links with local schools.The charity, based on Lothian Crescent, hopes to educate Tayside youngsters on global issues such as poverty and inequality. Until now, most of its work has been abroad, helping communities in countries such as Brazil, Tanzania, Uganda and the Philippines.Michael Calder, programmes and learning officer at Signpost, said: “We’ve really been trying to strategise how we can best make use of this centre. It’s very much underused at the moment.“As an international development charity most of our work is overseas. We have done some work in Dundee, but we want to do more locally.”At present the centre serves as an office for the charity’s international projects and a base for other groups such as Addaction and Soul Garden. However, under the new proposals it will house a fully-fledged community cafe, expanded garden facilities and an auditorium equipped with projectors and IT equipment.Signpost will also, using the latest technology, help Tayside youngsters understand global issues, including virtual reality headsets loaded with immersive films on topics such as walking several miles to fetch water.Michael added: “We’re reaching out to local schools to make them aware of our plans – butany want to approach us to talk about it we’re very open to that.”While most of the funding for the project is expected to come from charity grants, Signpost is holding an afternoon tea and live jazz fundraiser for additional support.The event takes place on March  from .-.pm at the Invercarse Hotel, on Perth Road, with tickets available for £..

title: i couldnt believe what i was seeing cops hunt teens spotted on railway track in carnoustie
story: Police and train operators are investigating after two teenagers were spotted standing on the tracks filming a train coming towards them.ScotRail confirmed it is looking into the incident which took place close to the Maltings Crossing in Carnoustie last week.Meanwhile, British Transport Police is appealing for anyone who has any information about the trespassing to come forward.Witness Tanya Alavuk, , alerted a nearby police officer after spotting the teenager on the tracks on Thursday.She said: “I couldn’t believe what I was seeing. It was horrying.“This boy was standing on the railway line filming the train that was coming towards him.“The train driver had obviously seen him too and managed to slow the train down.“The boy then stepped to the side and let the train pass.“I was with a friend and we initially thought that someone was about to jump in front of the train.“We didn’t know what to do but we saw police officers close by and ran to alert them.“They gave chase but the boy and another small group of young people ran away.“I dread to think what could have happened.”A spokesman for British Transport Police said a wheelie bin was also removed from the tracks.He said: “Officers were called to Carnoustie station at pm on Thursday February  following reports of two trespassers on the line.“BTP quickly attended but two young men had left the scene. A wheelie bin was removed the tracks.“Inquiries are currently ongoing. Officers would encourage anyone who saw what happened or has any information to contact them by texting  or calling     quoting reference  of   .”A spokesman for ScotRail said the driver of Edinburgh to Aberdeen service reported trespassers on the line near Carnoustie shining a torch.He said that the trespassers ran off as the train approached. The train was subsequently delayed by around  minutes as a wheelie bin had to be removed from the line.“We take this opportunity to remind people not to trespass anywhere on the railway as they put themselves and others at risk of serious injury.”Carnoustie councillor Mark McDonald said: ““The reports of teenagers on the track at Carnoustie Railway Station is deeply concerning and their actions go far beyond antisocial behaviour.“Trespassing on a railway line is incredibly dangerous, not only putting their lives in danger but also putting passengers and staff on the train at risk.“I would urge anyone with any information to get in touch with the British Transport Police.”

The annual passes offer great value for families, couples and adults as they can be used all year round.”Passes can be bought in person at the museum, or online at dmoft.

title: plans to turn former dundee whisky bond into block of modern flats
story: A former whisky bond could be transformed into a block of modern flats under a new proposal put to city planners.The upper floors of the B-listed Robertson Bond on Seagate have lain unused for  years, since last occupants, Dundee Printmakers Workshop, left in  for the DCA.Development firm Appletree Bond Limited – based in Dundee’s Vision Building – wants to repurpose the floors overlooking the Seagate into one and two-bed flats.The hopeful investors have submitted a planning application to Dundee City Council through Voigt Architects in which they have outlined their hopes for the building.In all, they hope to create  flats, with some facing on to Seagate and others looking to the north, away from the street.A comprehensive ventilation system has been included in the application because of the building’s age.Storage space has been set aside for bicycles in line with council planning policies. However, the applicants have not included any provision for car parking space as no room is available on the site.They hope motorists would be happy to park in nearby Gellatly Street instead.In a statement included with the application on Appletree’s behalf, Voigt said: “The proposal will restore and reuse a redundant listed building which is falling into disrepair.“ will create modern apartments that will support the housing stock for Dundee, helping to address the accommodation shortage.“The overall development will be of a high quality to revitalise an existing listed building.”Built in  for John Robertson and Company – famous for its “yellow label” whisky – the building was later used as a print gallery between -.While the upper floors have been unused since then, the ground floor is occupied by independent clothing shop Arkive.Appletree’s bid is not the first application to be put forward to reinvent the Robertson Bond in recent times.A similar application for  flats was approved in , and another for  flats was accepted in .The local authority confirmed it received the application on Thursday.Planners have until April  to make a decision.

title: suspicious package that washed up in the tay was a hindu good luck greeting
story: Dundee police have revealed the mystery package which washed up in the Tay was in fact a good luck message – written in Urdu.The discovery of the item prompted emergency crews to race to the scene on the esplanade in front of Bridgeview Station Restaurant.Firefighters and police rapidly established the small box, which contained a plastic wrapped package, was not dangerous to the public.Officers taped off an area covering five parking spaces and the section of pavement while carrying out a probe.Vehicles were also stopped from entering the car park close to the road block, but there was no evacuation of the area.Now a spokesman for police in Dundee has disclosed, after almost two weeks of investigating, that the package contained animal hide with a message inside.The spokesman told the Tele: “It was an animal skin wrapped in a bag, and inside the rolled up hide was a note written in Urdu.“We had it translated and apparently it’s some kind of good luck charm, whereby you write the note, wrap it in animal skin, cast it into the water, and it brings you good luck.”One witness at the riverside scene – which took place on Monday February  – said at the time: “It was quite exciting.“The package was about the size of a binoculars case and when it was opened there were other cellophane wrapped packages inside.”He added that his immediate thought then was it could be a drugs parcel which had been ditched into the water – but he felt nobody could have guessed what was actually wrapped up inside the box before it was eventually uncovered.Firefighters stood down as soon as it was confirmed there was no danger to the public and police began examining the package further.One officer wearing rubber gloves removed the parcel at around .pm.A police spokeswoman at the time thanked the member of the public who reported the package while walking along the esplanade.She added: “The member of the public did exactly the right thing by contacting us immediately.“He was very vigilant and as soon as he spotted the package he called us and we responded accordingly.”

title: scott-bain-scorns-embarrassing-and-pathetic-motherwell
story: Scott Bain could take the title for the most laidback character in the Celtic dressing room but the affable goalkeeper was still incensed  hours after Motherwellrsquos controversial goal on Sunday afternoon.Ultimately it counted for little more than a statistical note but for the current incumbent of the number one shirt, it unravelled  domestic clean sheets and undone what he described as a considerable body of work in the process.Gboly Ariyibirsquos goal after Celtic had put the ball out for Ryan Christie to be treated for what looked like a hamstring pull was the first the Parkhead side had conceded domestically on their own turf since October.And Bain did not take the slight lightly.ldquoI think itrsquos pretty embarrassing, pretty pathetic that they felt they had to try that to score a goal, he said. ldquoIt was disappointing to lose the record like that. Not that we really thought or spoke about it but I donrsquot think we were too far away from getting to the record of clean sheets and wersquod got there by playing some very good football.ldquoItrsquos disappointing. Something Irsquove never seen before. Itrsquos a bit embarrassing to be honest. Irsquom sure they woke up on Monday morning and were a bit embarrassed of how theyrsquove handled it. They had the chance to recty the situation after and did nothing about it.ldquoThe amount of work that we put in to those games before with the clean sheets, the way we defendedhellip and itrsquos gone out of the window for something that shouldnrsquot really happen in football.ldquoFor us to come in and them to say lsquoyou won the game anywayrsquo hellip thatrsquos just absolutely pathetic.James Scott set the goal up when he latched onto a throw-in that Liam Grimshaw had put into the left channel. As play slowed anticipating a casual passing of the ball back, it quickly became apparent that the teenager was going for goal.Scott looked sheepish as he left the pitch later in the game, almost apologising to his bench, and Motherwell manager Stephen Robinson cited the inexperience of the player as the reason for the goal that flouted convention.Bain, though, was scornful of the reasons offered as he insisted that the responsibility for it ought to have been taken by the Motherwell management.ldquoTheir manager tried to blame it on a young lads but yoursquod got the chance to recty the situation after and they donrsquot do it, said Bain.ldquoI dunno. So, what has [Scott] not watched football before  Hersquos not played a game before  Youth team levels all the way up, it happens at every level. I thinkyou are the manager you have to recty the situation.ldquoI donrsquot understand what he was thinking. Hersquos tried to blame it on a young lad but hersquos in charge. So between him and the rest of the players they can sort it out. But obviously they didnrsquot want to. They wanted to try and get a second goal and get a point or go on to win the game.It will be interesting to note just what happens in the next fixtures between the sidesthere is a similar scenario of a player on either side requiring treatment. Bainrsquos fury was still simmering as he suggested that he would be playing tit-for-tat in any future matches, but that would seem unlikely given Brendan Rodgersrsquo is always at pains to stress a respect for opponents.Still, though,it was up to Bain there would be no such understanding.ldquoIf it was up to me  No. Not a chance, he said. ldquoIn future wersquoll probably just play with  men and not put the ball out of play. So our players could be lying down seriously injured. But it happened and we go from there.ldquoMost of the boys were angry and they have the right to be. It is not something we would do and it is not something I have seen anyone do, really. They have the right to be angry and for five or ten minutes it disjointed us a little bit and they came into the game but after the game against Valencia and how much all the boys put into that game and to power through again and get another two goals and win comfortably says a lot about the character in the team."

title: Climate action call comes to Inverness streets
story: CLIMATE change activists from the Black Isle and Inverness have shown their solidarity for school pupils across the world after the youngsters held a lsquostrikersquo to flag up ecological concerns.New group Extinction Rebellion Highlands and Islands held a stall in Inverness High Streetlast Saturday, asking passers-by to sign a petition calling for urgent action by Highland Council to do its bit to tackle the threat, amid growing worries that the planetrsquos global warming is nearing an irreversible tipping point.Organised by Black Isle activist Anne Thomas, who is also involved with Transition Black Isle, the stall attracted  signatures in the space of  minutes.The youth strike, which included Highland participants, was sparked by Swedish teenager Greta Thunberg who spoke at the last major UN Climate Change summit saying adults were not doing enough and time was running out.ldquoLots of people had been impressed by the stand the kids had taken and were keen to show their support, said Ms Thomas. ldquoThey agreed that government at all levels is not doing enough to stop dangerous levels of global warming and climate change.ldquoScientists say we have less than  years to prevent warming going over . degrees, so we need to take drastic measures now. We could be on the brink of a mass extinction like the one which wiped out the dinosaurs.ldquoThe petition asked that the Highland Council... reverse inconsistent policies and work alongside the media to communicate with residents.The petition also called on the local authority to pass a climate emergency motion to make the region carbon neutral by .Fiona Cormie who has just taken on the role of co-ordinator of the group, said they hoped to add ldquosignicantly to its number of petition signatories in the coming weeks and present them to the council.Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: Disaled workers getting a raw deal new report claims
story: MANY disabled people in Scotland have been ldquofrozen out of work due to their condition, according to research by disability charity Leonard Cheshire.Three out of four said they left their jobs because they had not received the support they needed to fulfil their role, and nearly one out of five who applied for a job in the past five years felt the employer had chosen not to consider them for the post because they had a disability.Kenny Shand from Inverness who found himself in this situation, said: ldquoNot everyone is treated with respect. Whether you have additional support needs or not, the system needs to be more transparent. Workplace adjustments donrsquot need to be expensive ndash they just need to be done.Stuart Robertson, director at Leonard Cheshire in Scotland, said the findings lt the lid on a ldquotough and unwelcoming employment landscape.He said: ldquoMost people with disabilities in  remain frozen out of the world of work. All of us must redouble our efforts to challenge outdated attitudes to disability and accelerate the positive change that enables everyone to thrive in the world of work.The research also suggests more than half of all managers consider the cost of workplace adjustments a barrier to employing people with disabilities.In more promising news, Leonard Cheshirersquos research found a fth of employers say they are more likely to employ someone with a disability.The charity said the latest research shows an increased awareness amongst employers of the UK Governmentrsquos Access to Work scheme giving people grant and other support based on their needs, is up to  percent in  from  percent in .But many recipients are waiting more than three months for their application to be approved and the charity wants government action.Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: First phase of 32m refurbishment completed at Inverness school
story: THE first phase of a major refurbishment programme at an Inverness primary school has been completed.Two new classrooms have opened at Smithton Primary, much to the delight of principal teacher Lynne Macdonald who said the new facilities increased opportunities for its  children as well as staff.Pupils have also got a new a multiuse games area.ldquoItrsquos made a huge dference, she said.ldquoIt gives us a lot more space and just little things like having blackout blinds on sunny days and having all the children in seats at the same height really helps.The pound. million refurbishment project to address the schoolrsquos current and future capacity needs began last April.Once completed, it will see a total of five additional classrooms created along with two support needs rooms, a dedicated space for senior pupils and an extended gym hall.Local councillor Trish Robertson said it was excellent to see the project start to take shape.ldquoThe expansion was badly needed and having the extra space must be better for the children, she said. ldquoIrsquom really pleased itrsquos gone up so quickly.Iain MacDonald, special works manager for Morgan Sindall, which is carrying out the renovation work, said construction was currently on track for completion by September.ldquoThe most important thing for us has been not to interrupt the daily activity of the school, he said.ldquoBut another big thing is giving the kids a good experience of construction ndash therersquos a perception that construction is about the trades but therersquos so much more to get involved in.Miss Macdonald added: ldquoThe workers have been great. They always make sure they receive any deliveries before am which really helps and means the construction isnrsquot impacting the children. Thatrsquos the most important thing.Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: Funding blow to Highland food banks charity
story: North-based charity Blythswood Care has issued a public appeal for more donations after it lost an annual pound, recycling grant from Highland Council in the recent local authority budget.The charity which has one of the largest networks of food banks in the Highlands handles around  tonnes of clothing donations a year at its Evanton depot of which more than  per cent was reused or recycled.Previously the council financially supported the recycling work and some local authority properties already host textile banks for taking unwanted clothing deposits but this year withdrew support.The council had to plug an almost pound million financial hole in its budget amid shrinking government grants for core services, the moves was called a ldquobody blow by operations manager Ian Matheson who admitted the loss of the recycling grant is not a complete surprise.ldquoWe recognise that the Council has been faced with hard decisions. Wersquove enjoyed a mutually beneficial partnership with Highland Council for over  years and we really appreciate that, he said.ldquoTheir support has enabled us to develop our re-use and recycling activities, reducing waste, providing local employment and raising support for projects such as Blythswoodrsquos Highland Food Bank.ldquoDonations of clothing, bric-a-brac and quality furniture from the general public are going to be more important to us than ever as we aim to continue this aspect of our work despite the loss of this grant.The organisation processes more than , tonnes of donations a year at its Evanton depot, producing goods for its charity shops and selling on to processors in other parts of the country.Mr Matheson said ldquoWe have to constantly review all that we do and consider what efficiencies we can make. You can help us now by giving our shops your custom and donations.ldquoAll donations will be gratefully received so we can have continuity of employment ndash because this is about jobs too ndash as well as maintain service provision.A council spokeswoman said: ldquoWe have had very positive discussions with Blythswood and these are ongoing about how we can possibly work together in the future.Blythswood welcomes donations of textiles, footwear, bric-a-brac, small electrical goods, books and good quality furniture.Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: Highland Council investing extra in roads maintenance
story: Highland Council is hoping an additional pound. million for maintenance announced as part of this yearrsquos budget will make a ldquonoticeable dference across the region.The funding, approved as a priority area for the revenue budget, will be shared out across Highland with area committees able to decide how to prioritise it more locally.Chairman of the councilrsquos environment, development and infrastructure committee, Councillor Allan Henderson, said: ldquoWe have the most extensive network of roads in the UK and, added to this, we are faced with some of the most severe weather conditions in the Highlands.ldquoThe freeze-thaw conditions in particular cause immense damage to road surfaces and this is very evident in the past few weeks.ldquoRoad conditions are a high priority for local residents and this was very clear in our recent engagement with communities and local representatives.ldquoThe additional resource will, I hope, make a noticeable dference and can be allocated to the roads with the most urgent need of repairs, right across the Highlands.Area allocations based on road mileage and population are:Badenoch  Strathspey: pound, Caithness: pound,Inverness: pound, Lochaber: pound, Nairn: pound,Ross  Cromarty: pound,Isle of Skye: pound,Sutherland: pound,Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: Hotel plan for Inverness car park site
story: PLANS which would see a city centre car park transformed into a six-storey hotel have been unveiled.The pound million proposal by developer SRP Inverness Ltd was displayed to the public at the Spectrum Centre on Farraline Park, immediately next to the two-deck Rose Street car park which is earmarked as the site for the -metre high hotel.The proposal is the latest city hotel development from SRP Inverness directors Stewart Campbell and Stuart McCaffer, who were also behind the creation of the Inverness Encore Hotel, now the Pentahotel, on nearby Academy Street.Mr Campbell is confident the -bedroom L-shaped building will attract interest from a globally-known hotel brand, bringing something new to the Inverness accommodation mix.ldquoWe have worked with a number of global brands over the years, he said.ldquoInverness has massive global tourism and a lot of people, particularly global travellers, want the comfort of a well-known global brand.ldquoInverness is a strong tourism market, but therersquos been a lack of supply over the years. Other than the Travelodge on Academy Street in , there hasnrsquot been a new hotel built in Inverness since .The proposal includes a gym, three retail units within the hotel footprint and parking for  cars.Mr Campbell believes the hotel will benefit from its proximity to Inverness bus and railway stations, while any under capacity at the car park would be compensated by the nearby multi-storey car park.Mr Campbell and Mr McCaffer also own the neighbouring Rose Street Hall, which they hope to utilise for retail or restaurant use once the hotel is completed.Between the two, they also plan to construct a new bus and taxi road, replacing the footpath linking the bus station and Rose Street retail units.SRP Inverness expects to apply for planning permission in mid-April.Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: Inverness MP calls for cross party approach to secure post Brexit funding
story: INVERNESS MP Drew Hendry has issued a cross-party rally cry ahead of Brexit.He has written to the Scotland spokespeople of each of the main political parties urging them to put pressure on the UK government to prevent Scotland losing out on millions of pounds in EU funding,the UK leaves the EU.Mr Hendry, the SNPs business spokeman, has called on parties to work together to ensure the UK government delivers a like-for-like replacement for vital EU development funds in the event of Brexit.Mr Hendry said: ldquoCommunities across Scotland would be hit hard by the loss of millions of pounds in vital EU fundingthe UK government drags us out of the EU against our will."The best way to protect this funding is for Scotland to remain in the EU - as we voted overwhelmingly for - butBrexit does go ahead then the UK government must commit to replacing every single penny of the funding Scotland stands to lose."It is shocking that the UK government has already broken its own word, and failed to consult on detailed plans to replace the lost EU funding and the huge benefits it brings for Scotland.ldquoIn addition to the many other benefits of our EU membership, Scotland has enjoyed huge investment in jobs, communities and infrastructure from European funds. It is vital that this investment continues like-for-like, and that the Scottish Government continues to oversee the funding so it meets Scotlands needs.ldquoAt present, groups across the country need to make decision about their future, but have no idea what sort of funding will be available after . This must not be another power grab away from the Scottish Parliament.ldquoSome of this funding helps level the playing field of regional inequality, which is stark when comparing rural areas with urban parts. The Tories must be held to account, investment levels must be matched, and clarity must be given to communities across Scotland.ldquoThe UK government cannot continue to kick this issue into the long grass and weasel out of their responsibilities. It is time for MPs and MSPs of all parties to demand that this money is protected in full and in time to give certainty to communities across Scotland."Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: Opinion divided on how to tackle Inverness gull menace
story: TIDY streets could be a more effective deterrent to Invernessrsquos seagull menace than culling, according to the RSPB.The suggestion comes in response to a call for a limited cull by city businessman Charlie Barbour.Mr Barbour, who owns city centre bars The White House and The Dog House as well as commercial property agency Barbour Commercial, suggests that destroying a small number of nesting pairs would make the centre of Inverness more attractive, safer and quieter.Describing the birds as ldquonoisy, dirty, aggressive and a blight on the city centre, Mr Barbour questions whether the Inverness Business Improvement Districtpolicy of removing eggs each year is enough to permanently reduce the gull population.ldquoWhilst a cull of such birds is not a universally popular decision, I just wonderthere is merit in destroying say three or four nesting pairs of seagulls each year, he writes.ldquoA reduction in seagull numbers would improve the city centre experience for visitors and that surely has to be a good thing However, a spokeswoman for conservation charity the RSPB said that lethal control should only ever be a last resort, used only where there is a proven problem and other alternatives have proven ineffective. Instead, local authorities, businesses and iniduals should tackle the problem by reducing the birdsrsquo food supply by cutting down the amount of edible litter and introducing gull-proof litter bins.Other non-lethal options include putting up physical barriers such as netting on roofs as a deterrent before the breeding season.ldquoWe believe that gull problems in an urban environment are best tackled by reducing the availability of food and nest sites. If the features that attract gulls remain, any `vacanciesrsquo created by controlling existing gulls will simply be filled by other gulls moving in, she said.Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: Roads not safe for city cyclists says Inverness campaigner
story: A LOT needs to be done to bring roads in Inverness up to a standard that makes them safe and easy for road users to navigate, a leading cycling campaigner has said.Brian MacKenzie, convener of the Highland Cycle Campaign, said: ldquoI cycle a lot and there is no doubt the roads in the town are in very poor condition.ldquoThe trunk roads, too, need attention.Championing the cause for better and safer routes for cyclists he said drivers also need to be aware of cyclists and give greater consideration to them.ldquoDrivers often criticise cyclists when they see them weaving along certain routes but often they are doing that simply to avoid potholes and are taking evasive action, he said.ldquoAt the Raigmore Interchange, on the ramp joining the A south from the A, there is a pothole which has been there for some time. It is now gathering water and there is a warning sign for traffic alerting them to flooding.ldquoThere are also two more long potholes which are much more dangerous for cyclists and motorists just as you enter the interchange off the northbound ramp, coming from the Beechwood direction of the A.ldquoThe seal between the interchange and the ramp has gone andyou are cycling along there on a dark night you canrsquot see it, so your wheel can get caught up in it. These are like tram lines and they could throw you off a bike and cause serious injury.ldquoEvery vehicle coming from the A has to go across these potholes as they enter the interchange as well and they have been like that for a considerable time.ldquoI am wondering when the trunk roads people are going to carry out these repairs.While Highland Council is responsible for the upkeep of most roads in Inverness and the surrounding towns and villages, Bear Scotland is responsible for trunk roads.A spokesman for the organisation told the Courier last week that major defects, including deeppotholes which could pose a danger to road users, are repaired within  days, with safety inspections of all roads under its care inspected on a weekly basis.Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: Stonework to be refurbished at Invernesss Victorian Market

title: Sugars night set to be sweet for Highland Hospice
story: AN evening of fun, quality entertainment and good food has been promised by an Inverness man who is raising money for the Highland Hospice.Alastair Kennedy, communications director at Global Energy Group and chairman of Nigg Skills Academy, is calling on local businesses to try and help with his fundraising for this yearrsquos Strictly Inverness dancing competition.The -year-old said: ldquoIrsquom hoping that the business community will support this amazing cause as they have done in the past.Known to his friends as Sugar, Mr Kennedy will be hosting a dinner called Sugarrsquos Strictly Big Night at the Kingsmills Hotel in Inverness on April .The black tie tartan event will consist of live music from local band Torridon as well as an auction, quiz and a raffle, with all proceeds going to the hospice.Mr Kennedy is reaching out to the local business community to come along and support the event so he can raise as much money as possible.The director of Ross County Football Club is well known for his enjoyable hosting of hospitality at their home matches over the past  years, and thinks he has the the expertise and dry sense of humour to host another entertaining and enjoyable evening for all.As the oldest ever competitor in Strictly Inverness, Mr Kennedy was inspired to get involved in this yearrsquos event after sadly losing his mother to cancer in . She spent her final days in the hospice.ldquoTheir facilities and the care they provided for my mum was just so wonderful and considerate, he said.ldquoThey looked after her so well in her last days with us. I said at the time that I must, at some point in the future, do something to raise much-needed funds for the hospice, and with it being their th Strictly anniversary year, I just thought maybe now is the time.ldquoThere are lots of couples competing for the Strictly Inverness title and there is already great camaraderie being built up between us all.ldquoThis is not so much about winning, itrsquos more about raising money for this most worthy cause and everyone is working so hard not just in dance training, but in raising money by whatever means. I am hoping my business connections will assist me in being able to create a great night, but also raise as much money as possible for the hospice.Tables cost pound for  people and anyone interested should contact Mr Kennedy via Global Energy Group.Strictly Inverness also raises money for Inverness Ice Centre, which hosts the showdown from May .Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: 40 flats planned for site of former aberdeen nursing home
story: Plans to build almost  flats on the grounds of a former nursing home have been given the go-ahead.Bancon Developments has lodged an application to build the -unit development on Union Grove, Aberdeen.The site forms part of the larger grounds of the former nursing home Nazareth House, now known as Aspire Grove.Under the plans, two buildings would be built fronting Union Grove, both containing  flats.In their decision report, council planners said the area is designated for residential use in the Aberdeen Local Development Plan.They added the proposal raises “no signicant” residential amenity concerns and the flats on the opposite side of Union Grove are m away, meaning there would be no loss of privacy or daylight.Two objections were lodged against the plans, claiming it would have an adverse impact on residents.

title: aberdeen butcher installs second defib following community support
story: An Aberdeen butcher is to install a second defibrillator near his shop after receiving overwhelming support from the community.HS Milne and Sons in Bucksburn already has the vital le-saving piece of equipment set up outside its Inverurie Road branch but now, thanks to generous customers, provision will double in the area.The new defibrillator will be placed at Davy’s Fish Bar on Sclattie Park and has been bought thanks to the Butchers at the Heart of the Community initiative.The scheme, which is Scotland-wide, was set up by Hunters of Kinross and is supported by Scottish Craft Butchers, the Scotch Butchers Club and Save a Le Scotland.Its main aim is to help and encourage people to be ready and confident to use CPR equipment in the event of somebody suffering a cardiac arrest.Kenny Milne, owner of HS Milne and Sons, became involved with the scheme last summer.He said: “The community helped us raise money for the defibrillator which is outside the store.“It was installed in November. We originally only planned to install one but the money kept coming in and we had enough for another one so we spoke to Davy’s Fish Bar and they said they would back it.”The defibrillators can be purchased for around £, – a reduced price because they were bought in bulk through the Butchers at the Heart of the Community scheme.Both defibrillators will be accessibly to the public when needed.If an emergency  call is made and the defibrillator is registered with the Scottish Ambulance Service, the nearest device can be located and a code given to the caller to unlock it.Once opened, instructions are provided.For heart-attack victims, the community defibrillators could prolong their lives by vital minutes, because the more time that passes during a cardiac arrest without assistance, the less chance there is of survival.Mr Milne said he was overwhelmed by the community’s generosity.He said: “Most of it was raised in the shop. We also raised about £ through a Just Giving page.“Local musicians put together a concert at Newhills Church, and a second one at Bucksburn Church which raised quite a bit of money. It was all raised by the community.”The equipment is expected to be installed shortly.Douglas Scott, chief executive of Scottish Craft Butchers, said: “This project is all about enabling butchers to save the lives of people in their community, raising money to provide defibrillators and training staff on how to do CPR.”

title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: ayrshire hospice marks 30th birthday
story: NewsAyrshire Hospice marks th birthday as staff and volunteers reflect on three decades of serviceThe milestone birthday has been marked with a series of events and celebrations.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  FEB News "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFor  years it has touched the lives of thousands in Ayrshire and far beyond. Its mission  To enrich the remaining days of those facing le-limiting illness. The work of the Ayrshire Hospice, irreplaceable since February , has formed part of the region’s fabric over three decades. But at pound, per day to fund bosses admit they owe their biggest debt to the public. Reflecting on the landmark birthday, chief executive Mandy Yule said: “Our message to the wonderful people of Ayrshire is ‘thank you’. “We wouldn’t be able to deliver the level of care we doit wasn’t for their support. “We have an incredible group of volunteers and fundraisers across Ayrshire, some of whom have given their time for over  years, and without the fundraising efforts the hospice wouldn’t be here.” Since opening its doors on Racecourse Road the base has become a centre of care, comfort, compassion and dignity to more than , patients.  But its true origins go back even further to a group of hard-working volunteers who set up their own trust in . Their goal was to raise the necessary funds to open a hospice in Ayrshire. After as initial target of pound, was met within  months the next task of finding a suitable location threw up Racecourse Road. Building work began in  and, with it, the hospice service was launched with the appointment of two home care nurses. From its earliest days fundraising has served the heart of the hospice. And it is that invaluable support that the hospice – which has almost  staff and volunteers – is recognising during its th year.   Mandy said: “Because of their efforts we have access to some of the best palliative care treatments available, allowing us to give our patients comfort and quality of le. “We have been privileged to give thousands of patients and their families the care and support they need, both at the hospice itself or wherever they have lived in Ayrshire, over the last  years and we take great pride in that”. To help mark the anniversary a special memory tree has been created giving the opportunity to leave reflections and memories of the hospice. Mandy said: “We never take the compassionate and continued support of the hospice by the people of Ayrshire for granted. “The memory tree gives people the chance to leave their own memories or thoughts about the hospice and be part of our celebration.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyr NewsAyr

title: jury asked convict ayr broadcaster
story: NewsJury asked to convict Ayr broadcaster Bryce Curdy on girl rape chargeHis defence claims evidence against him "doesnt stack up"ShareByStephen Houston:,  FEB NewsThe trial is taking place at the High Court in Glasgow "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA PROSECUTOR has urged a jury to convict broadcaster Bryce Curdy of raping a -year-old girl in the South of France. Liam Ewing told jurors: “You have heard how the girl described screaming as he raped her.” He added: “I ask you to examine the evidence. She goes into a lot of detail about what happened to her. I invite you toa guilty verdict.” The alleged victim, who is now , claimed that Curdy, , from Ayr, raped her three times. She alleged that on each occasion he whispered to her afterwards” If you tell anyone I will kill you and your mum.” Curdy, who is on trial at the High Court in Glasgow, denies raping her on ious occasions between April  and August , , at a house in the South of France. Mr Ewing told the jury that the Crown is relying on testimony from the girls mother, who is , to corroborate the rape. She alleges that Curdy also raped her in August  in the South of France. The mothers allegation, which he denies, is not before the jury. Under Scots Law alleged crimes against children committed in another country can be prosecuted here, but not those against adults. The mother claimed that after having consensual sex with her, Curdy went on to rape her. Defence counsel Lorenzo Alonzi told the jury: “If you apply the law, you will find that the correct verdict in this case is acquittal.” Mr Alonzi said in his closing speech that there was absolutely no independent evidence in this case – only the allegations of the girl and her mother. He went on: “There is no DNA evidence, there is no torn clothing, there is no medical evidence and no witnesses who heard screams. “The idea that there was this monstrous threat to kill her and her mum, it doesnt stack up.” Curdy claimed that the two woman made up the allegations about him after he demanded theof his pound, gold and diamond Rolex watch. The trial before judge Johanna Johnston QC continues.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSex crimeGlasgowAyrCourtsJusticeAyr News

title: malawi partners set top tour
story: NewsMalawi partners get set for top tour of AyrshireErnest Chirwa and Francis Juma from Bandawe All Girls Secondary School and Bandawe Primary School will embark on a tour of Ayrshire from March  - .ShareByAbi Smillie:,  FEB NewsFrancis Juma with Bill Duncan, Elder from Alloway Parish Church "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAlloway Parish Church are gearing up to welcome partnering head teachers from across the globe next month. Following the success of the Alloway Malawi Mission , the church, in partnership with Alloway and Doonfoot Primary Schools have invited two head teachers from their partner schools in northern Malawi to visit Ayrshire in March. Ernest Chirwa and Francis Juma from Bandawe All Girls Secondary School and Bandawe Primary School will embark on a tour of Ayrshire from March  - . A full itinerary has been organised including working with and observing the teachers and head teachers across local schools including Belmont Academy and Wellington School. Visits to Culzean Castle and Ayr Hospital have also been arranged.   The duo are very excited to meet the Provost and the Director of Lelong Learning of South Ayrshire Council. Ernest Chirwa and Francis Juma will attend worship at Alloway Parish Church on both Sundays, and will join families at Messy Church on March . And a fun-filled community “Scottish Night” with ceilidh dancing, entertainment and a quiz will be held in the church halls on Saturday, March  from . – pm, to really make the visitors welcome. Alloway and Doonfoot pupils are very excited to meet the head teachers and to learn more about their friends from Malawi. Mr Juma and Mr Chirwa will also be able to attend the wonderful Pop UK recording, with concerts set to be held in the church on March . And will be able to take back photographs and videos to share with their pupils, as well as a copy of the CD recorded by Alloway youngsters to share with their schools, church and communities.

title: volunteers bid breathe new life
story: NewsVolunteers bid to breathe new le into Ayr town centre with arts hubThe team behind the move say they will bring fresh ideas and creation to the towns bottom end.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  FEB News "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA bid to breathe new le into Ayr’s emptying High Street will be staged by hard working volunteers. The group insist a “cultural hub” can spark much needed footfall at the town’s tired bottom end. And they hope a plan to rent the former clothing store, Millets, will aid their cause. FreshAyr, the team behind the project, are not new to opening ‘pop-up’ spaces in the town. But boss Robert Singer, , insists: “We believe this next phase is potentially our most important. “Ayr has lost its place as a market town and tourist destination. “Long gone are the factories, fisheries and agricultural markets of the past – even retail is failing. “So there is a serious pressing need to rethink the way people engage with High Streets. “Our project will focus on the arts and use it as a force for regeneration.” The team have won a three month ‘proof of cause’ deal which, they hope, will lead in turn to later funding.   Robert explained: “We have a five year project in mind with this unit ideally being our permanent base. “Until now, we have operated around the town on a pop-up basis but that is never ideal. “We’d like this as our home.” The ‘BREAD arts lab’ will launch next month and run in conjunction with the project’s bakehouse, which is set to operate from Cathcart Street. Robert said: “We want people to engage with the process...to come in and literally see bread being made before their eyes before taking it home. “At our High Street base we will stage exhibitions, performances, music and art. “We want this to be a centre for everything creative.” •What is your view  Send us your opinion by email on news@ayrshirepost or give us a call on  .Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrAyr News

title: scottish-borders-council-leader-calls-for-brexit-funding-from-scottish-government
story: COUNCIL leader Shona Haslam and local MP John Lamont have criticised the Scottish Government for failing to provide enough money to councils in preparation for Brexit.According to the Scottish Conservatives, English local authorities have received pound. million over the past two years to help fund Brexit preparations, while Scottish councils have received nothing.This is despite the Scottish Government receiving pound. million in -, and pound million in -, from Westminster to prepare for leaving the EU.However, SNP MSPs have described the duo as having lsquoa real brass neckrsquo considering that responsibility for the Brexit referendum and the current state of negotiations with the EU are the responsibility of Westminster Conservatives.Councillor Haslam, who represents Tweeddale East, said: ldquoThis is quite unbelievable.ldquoThe SNP Government continues to squirrel away money and not pass it onto those who are actually doing the work.ldquoAs a local authority we are working incredibly hard to ensure that front line services are maintained and unaffected by Brexit, to hear that financial support has been given to the Scottish Government but it has, again, failed to be passed on is disheartening.SBC has been working on civil contingency plans in case of Brexit-related emergencies, including a taskforce that updates the council regularly.The group has been tasked with planning for emergency shortages in food, fuel and medicine which may arise as a result of trade disruption following the UKrsquos withdrawal from the EU.The councilrsquos emergency planning officers have advised the authority that its role in such situations would be to ensure vital services such as schools, waste disposal and social care, remain al.The Brexit response team has also provided the council with updates on the impacts on procurement, funding, EU residents in the Borders and the councilrsquos workforce, private business and economic resilience, and agriculture and rural development.Fellow Tory and Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk MP John Lamont said: ldquoOn an almost daily basis we hear from the SNP Government about the challenges of Brexit. Yet incredibly we now know that the Scottish Government hasnrsquot even spent the money it has been given to prepare for Brexit.ldquoIn England, councils have received nearly pound million, yet the SNP have provided no financial support for our own councils.ldquoThe fact that the SNP are now demanding more money just goes to show they are more interested in manufacturing a grievance than being a responsible Government.ldquoScottish Borders Council are quite rightly making plans to ensure that as we leave the EU there is minimal disruption for services and for businesses. And they are doing this without any support from the Scottish Government.However, the SNP said that ldquoBrexit is the Toriesrsquo mess, with MSP George Adam commenting: ldquoIt takes a real brass neck for the Tories to demand the SNP do more to clean up their Brexit mess while Westminster cuts deeper into Scotlandrsquos annual resource budget.ldquoThis shameless stunt by John Lamont to try pin the fallout of catastrophic Tory Brexit on the SNP is nothing short of embarrassing.ldquoEven before we have even left the EU, Brexit has already left households pound, worse off ndash with the economy at its weakest since .ldquoBrexit is the Toriesrsquo mess. No one rsquos. End of story.ldquoWe are now in the eleventh hour: John Lamont and his Tory colleagues in Westminster need to get their heads out of the clouds and extend Article  immediately for the sake of jobs, businesses and livelihoods across Scotland.

title: investigation-finds-it-was-necessary-for-officers-to-use-taser-during-incident-in-jedburgh
story: AN investigation has concluded that is was necessary and proportionate for police to use a Taser during an incident in the Borders last year.The Police Investigations and Review Commissionerlooked at cases in Jedburgh, Aberdeen and Carluke.And the independent reportfound the use of Tasers had been justied in all three instances.The device was deployed by Specially Trained Officersin Jedburgh in June when a -year-old man was reported to be in possession of a loaded crossbow.Assistant Chief Constable Mark Williams, operational and specialist support said: ldquoWe welcome the findings of these reports. Our number one priority is the protection of the public and it is really positive that the PIRC has recognised that in all of these incredibly challenging incidents our officers acted professionally.The training of around  STOs began at the end of May  with the first officers being operational in their local communities from June , .STOs are equipped with Taser X and are deployed throughout Scotland.
