title: families need more support in early years to give children best possible start
story: The first , days of a childrsquos le is a ldquocritical phase in their development and what happens during that period can have lelong consequences on their health and wellbeing, the Health and Social Care Committee said.Poverty, poor housing and parents with mental health problems can all have an effect on a childrsquos development, they said, with those who have adverse experiences in childhood more likely to suffer poorer health later in le.According to the MPsrsquo report, nearly a third of children have not reached a level of development known as ldquoschool readiness by the age of five.The cross-party group urged the Government to kick-start an early years ldquorevolution and take advantage of a ldquowindow of enormous opportunity.A spokesman for the Department of Health and Social Care said childrenrsquos health was a ldquokey priority for the Government.The committee recommended that councils, working with the local NHS and voluntary sector, should implement a cross-Government strategy to bring improved support for parents and children in their area.They also called for an improvement to the Governmentrsquos Healthy Child Programme, and said health visitor checks should begin before conception and extend beyond the age of two-and-a-half.The report highlighted the good work of the Flying Start programme in Wales, which provides support to children living in disadvantaged areas, as well as the Family Nurse Partnership in Scotland, Northern Ireland and parts of England.MP Paul Williams, who led the committee for the inquiry, said: ldquoThere is a crisis in childrenrsquos mental health in this country. But all we are seeing are cuts to health visiting, childrenrsquos centre closures and increasing child poverty.ldquoThe Government must now show inspiring leadership to help children get the best possible start in le.ldquoIf our country is serious about prevention and reducing health inequalities then we must make massive investments and drive coordinated action right at the start of le.Fiona Smith, the Royal College of Nursingrsquos professional lead for children and young peoplersquos nursing, said improving the health and wellbeing of the youngest children ldquoshould be a major priority for every society.She added: ldquoHealth visitors work on the frontline in local communities and make vital interventions from birth, helping to prevent illness and promote health and wellbeing ndash however, Government ambitions to increase the size of this workforce in England were not underpinned by a comprehensive workforce plan and as a result numbers are now flat-lining.ldquoThe committeersquos call for an lsquoEarly Years Revolutionrsquo is one that the Government and NHS England must demonstrate they share through investment, not just in health visitors, but in all parts of the nursing workforce that support children and young people.ldquoAnything less will see this revolution remain words on a page with families missing out on the very interventions that can be the dference between leading a healthy le, and not.Leader of the House of Commons, Andrea Leadsom, is chairing an inter-ministerial group on early years family support, and said the report showed there was ldquogrowing recognition of the importance of improving support.ldquoAs we continue our work and look to make signicant policy recommendations for the earliest years, we will consider the select committeersquos views very carefully, she said.A Department of Health and Social Care spokesman said: ldquoChildrenrsquos health is a key priority for this Government and we want every child to have the best start in le.ldquoThe NHS Long Term Plan has committed to make the NHS one of the best places in the world to give birth and expand provision of quality mental health support for new and expectant mothers and their families.ldquoThe Health Secretary has also set out his prevention vision, supporting good health and support for families to stop problems title: journalist jorge ramos says equipment seized at maduro interview
story: Mr Ramos, one of the most influential Spanish-speaking journalists in the US, told The Associated Press that Mr Maduro cut short the interview after  minutes when he was shown video on an iPad shot a day earlier of young Venezuelans eating food scraps out of the back of a rubbish truck.The Univision team left the Miraflores palace after two hours without having their telephones, footage or four cameras ed, Mr Ramos said.He said they were informed by intelligence agents that they would be deported on Tuesday, when they were already scheduled toto their base in Miami.ldquoThey stole my work, Mr Ramos said. ldquoMy job is to ask questions..@NicolasMaduro has detained a United States citizen  journalist @Univision anchor @jorgeramosnews  his news crew  seized their equipment because he didnrsquot like the questions he was being asked. https:t.co MQdbzbvljlmdash Marco RubioFebruary , Venezuelarsquos government denied Mr Ramosrsquo account.They accused him of trying to stage an Communications Minister Jorge Rodriguez said on Twitter.Mr Ramos, who interviewed Mr Madurorsquos mentor, Hugo Chavez, three times, said Mr Maduro accused him of siding with the governmentrsquos opponents in the political fight for power now raging in Venezuela.More than  governments around the world have recognised opposition leader Juan Guaido as Venezuelarsquos rightful leader after Mr title: co armagh orchard lights up for valentine s celebration of love and cider
story: GRAEME COUSINS talks to a family in the Orchard County who have turned their harvest crop into a craft drink that is growing in reputationAs Valentine’s Day approaches, an orchard in Co Armagh has been transformed into a unique location to take the apple of one’s eye.Pat and Peter McKeever on the family farmA stunning light installation at Long Meadow farm on the outskirts of Portadown has created an atmosphere for love to blossom and for families to enjoy some quality time, while showcasing the craft cider that is produced on site.The farm and associated orchard has been in the McKeever family for nearly  years. When he was in his s, Pat McKeever took over the farm after the death of his father Peter, who had run an apple canning business on the site. Pat said: “My daddy was one of three brothers who used to can apples. They’d get the apples from the local orchards, peel them and can them. Daddy then started growing his own apples and supplying the fresh market and the cider markets.”Now Pat’s son, and Peter’s grandson – also called Peter – is the third generation farmer who is set to carry on the business. Pat’s we Catherine and their four daughters also have integral roles to play as the craft cider making end of the agri-business continues to grow.Pat, Catherine and Peter McKeever of Long Meadow FarmLong Meadow started off with two craft cider drinks in  before introducing a mulled cider and a cider aged in oak barrels, some of which had been used in the original apple canning business. Over the past two years the company has branched out into flavoured ciders, apple juice and apple cider vinegar – famed for its health benefits.Catherine said: “I know everything goes through a bit of a fad, but I think the craft ciders are still holding their own. The mindset of cider has changed with craft ciders. “A lot of people would have associated cider in their younger days – maybe when they were at university – as a cheap drink you can buy in big quantities and get a hit off.“But that wasn’t craft cider. People are prepared to pay that little bit extra for the quality that comes with craft cider.“We’re using all our own fruit. We make it in smaller quantities so it can hold all the flavours, that’s the way we want to keep it. We only use hand-picked fruit, not any that has fallen on the ground.”Of the harvesting process, Pat said: “We would have between  to  pickers. They would come the third week in July and do a bit of summer pruning.Resurfacing works on A Portadown Road, ArmaghBrexit and data protection - will firms still have to comply with the new EU GDPR  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "PORT | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "PORT | Article Teaser"“Once that’s finished, in August they start into the picking of the apples, that goes right through to the end of October, first week in November.“The picking season we call it the nine weeks of hell. It’s your livelihood. You are depending on that fruit.“We harvest approximately , tonne of apples yearly.”Catherine explained how the orchard came to be illuminated: “A man called Walter Holt came to the farm last year to buy some apple cider vinegar. “I got talking to him and he gave me his card and told me what he did – an outdoor lighting artist.“I didn’t think much of it at the time, but I think the seeds had been sewn. I played about with it in my mind for a long time that it could be something we could work with.”Walter Holt and his assistant Orlanda Delaforce spent a total of  hours working on the installation of the lighting scheme.Walter commented: “The challenge on this particular scheme was working with smaller trees in an orchard setting. It’s a compact area and our solution was to develop a one way circular trail. “We tried to have as much creative iety as possible, implementing dferent approaches to dferent trees, with the whole colour scheme carefully thought out.”The light display is accompanied by music composed by Londonderry musician Sharon Graham.Catherine said: “We chose Valentine’s week for the treelumination launch as we felt it was a novel way in terms of adding to the romance of walking in the moonlight, but it’s by no means just for couples, it’s designed very much as a family experience for everyone.“I think we all have a vision of apple orchards complete with apple blossom or an abundance of fruit.“This illuminations event highlights the orchards in a totally dference perspective – a raw natural resting state before the cycle of growth begins.”The light show – designed by Walter Holt of Travelling Treeluminations – is the first of its kind to be held in an orchard environment and will open to the public from today until Saturday, from pm to pm each evening at  Loughgall Road.Entry is £ per adult and £ for children. A family ticket for two adults and two children costs £.Visitors will be given the opportunity to see the pressing and blending facilities on the farm as well as taste some of the products.Artisan food will be on sale as well as some free refreshment including tea, coffee and hot chocolate. Set to benefit from the four-day event is local charity ‘Katie-Rose’s Journey’.For more information on this week’s illumination event and other aspects of the farm go to www.longmeadowcidertry catch  TrendingThree vehicle crash near PortadownPartner and child were lsquomaking too much noisersquoDiscovery of mans body sparks murder probeJail sentence for man who spat and screamed at hospital staffConcern as disabled woman who carrys oxygen tank slapped with parking ticket          .. title: uncertainty interconnectors and the future of ni energy post brexit
story: Posted on Monday February  by Ulster Business With a potential ‘no deal’ around the corner on Brexit, what will that mean for the future of Northern Ireland’s energy policy – especially on renewables, the I-SEM all-island market and power generation  John Simpson takes a closer look On the last working day before Christmas , the System Operator for Northern Irelandpublished draft proposals of how the electricity systems and grids on this island may operate in -. Subject to confirmation by the all-island Single Electricity Market Committee, the auction for electricity generators to be awarded capacity contracts, on an all-island basis, has identied electricity capacityof , MW which will be in place for the year starting October ,  – , MW of that all-island total is attributed to Northern Ireland.This is a critical series of draft decisions which will reassure the large conventional generators about their contracts and will impose the discipline of revenue limits constrained by the capacity auction. The draft decisions also point to the expectations in terms of the capacity earmarked from renewable sources, from inter-connection with the Scottish grid and the capacity adjustments that may follow from demand-side adjustment contracts.SONI has not been as open and transparent as should have been possible. Readers must make the assumption that ties location to where capacity payments are identied in sterling and euro.The SONI statement lists  generator names ,  of which are identied as DSUswhich leaves  others. Eight are shown as part of the AES capacity in Ballylumford and Kilroot: four are small capacity generators, six each have capacity of over MW , and the last capacity source linked to Northern Ireland is the Moyle Interconnector.SONI does not present the capacity awards in a way that allows readers to identy the location of each successful unit.The Utility Regulator has agreed that the available Northern Ireland capacity should include  MW from the Moyle Interconnector which represents over % of locally available capacity. This is a judgement that might be queried. Is the interconnectora guaranteed source of capacity  If, at a time of peak demand in Northern Ireland, demand in the grid in GB had no spare capacity, presumably the capacity might not be available for supply to Northern Ireland. The regulator and SONI are well placed to judge the probability of this outcome and might argue that it is a minimal risk.There are some interesting features stemming from the assumptions made in setting the framework for the capacity auction. First, Northern Ireland has been treated as meriting some contract iations because of locational constraints. This is a reflection of the limited capacity of the electricity grid on the whole island to send electricity to the places where there is demand. Both the Dublin area and Northern Irelanddid not attract auction bids adequately to supply these area locational constraints. For Northern Ireland. the easy explanation lies in the absence of the long awaited north-south grid expansion from to the planned distribution hub in Co Tyrone.The capacity auction allowed for the acceptance of bids with prices which are higher than the main auction prices which would match supply and demand across the whole island. Because of the locational deficit, some Northern Ireland bids now show capacity payment prices above the all-Ireland ceiling of £, per MW which applies to most of the successful bids.In the quotation from AES for the two large fossil fuel burning units, the proposal is that they should attract payment prices of £, and £, per MW. At first sight this appears to allow a premium of nearly % on the payment price for each MW. This seems more than a marginal cost and points to the possible cost savingsthe proposed new north-south link had been operational.This answer for the older high capacity units at Kilroot is a further reflection of the doubt about the continued viability of these units. It will be remembered that a year ago, these same two units were deemed unsuccessful in the auction but, at a late stage when faced with a request for a derogation to be allowed to close these units, the initially agreed settlement was revised.A year ago, the first capacity auction under the rules of the newly instituted I-SEM, was accepted with a capacity supply of near to , MW for all of Northern Ireland. Now, in early , SONI has concluded that for security of supply Northern Ireland should contract for just under , MW. There is no obvious major uplt in demand in Northern Ireland so that, quietly, the suggestion is that the arithmetic in late  may now be thought to have been slightly too risky.The capacity auction is a fundamental building block of electricity supply policy for Northern Ireland. However, on its own, the allocation of capacity and the possible scope for investment in new generating capacity must also be seen in the context of increasing,market forces allow, the proportion of electricity supply that is supplied from renewable sources. The distribution of generating capacity is still dominated by fossil fuels. Northern Ireland’s capacity is nearly % from gas andcoal. However, the statistics showing the proportion of electricity supply from renewables points to average consumption from renewables of nearer to -%. Because of the iability in the contribution of wind based renewables, it would be hazardousgreater security dependence was allocated to renewables.In turn, the caveat about the possible role of renewables points to the possible value of further investment in energy storage for which no major scheme has been launched. If Kilroot power station survives for a further three to four years, then the experimental electricity storage capacity on that site may become an attractive asset.There are several continuing questions about Northern Ireland’s security of electricity supply. Will Kilroot be given further stays of execution after   Will the North South interconnector eventually be built  Will the proposed large natural gas burning power station be built in Belfast  Will the politically unpopular investment in anaerobic digestion plants be tackled  Will the Brexit settlement, or lack of it, damage the continued operation of the all-island single electricity market  But... it seems Kilroot has been given a temporary extension of its role in keeping the lights on.View all articlesSearch ulsterbusiness -- --SearchSearch -- --Follow us -- -- copy  Ulster Business Designed  Built by Laposa, Powered by Onxshop

title: ryder cup legend to address belfast leadership conference
story: Posted on Friday February  by Ulster Business Ryder Cup legend Paul McGinley has been revealed as one of the key speakers at a leadership event taking place in Belfast next month. The Management  Leadership SuMMit will see a host of top speakers, including the golfing great, turning out to Titanic Belfast on March , which will see Ulster Business as media partner. Paul McGinley achieved his place in golfing folklore by holing the winning putt on his Ryder Cup debut in  and, in , he became the first Irishman to captain the Ryder Cup Team, leading the European team to a memorable victory. In the year that The Open s to Northern Ireland, Paul will share his views on ‘leadership and a winning mindset’. Paul will be joined by other speakers including Paul C Dwyer, an expert on risk and cyber-security, Caspar Berry, Judith Gillespie CBE, entrepreneur Dave Linton and economist Neil Gibson. The Management  Leadership SuMMit will take place at Titanic Belfast on Friday, March . title: osborne king developing and nurturing talent within
story: Posted on Monday  February  by Ulster Business We speak to three of Osborne King’s team about moving up through the commercial property firm and what sets it apart from the competition From the outset, it’s clear that Northern Ireland commercial property firm Osborne King puts its people at the forefront of how the business operates and succeeds.Growing into a team of more than  staff, it’s a specialist commercial property consultancy based in Belfast – working for clients across the UK and Ireland. Its surveying team are members of the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors . Nurturing talent and progression is a core principle that the firms stands for with  of their surveying staff having become qualied throughout the firm’s training program. We sat down with three members of the team.Gail Prentice-Jackson, associate director Over the last  years, Gail has worked right across the business, now within the asset management department.She manages a large mixed-use portfolio of property which includes leading shopping centres and retail parks right across Northern Ireland.Within that her role is ied and includes managing one of Northern Ireland’s most successful retail schemes. Day-to-day this can include everything from managing service charge budgets to maximising rental income through lease renewals and rent reviews. Another key role is to provide regular accounting and financial reports to clients.“One of my key roles is to support my agency department colleagues in their  acquisitions of investment assets and upon completion ensure that a comprehensive management regime is followed to ensure continued growth of our clients assets,” she says.“The role of a ‘property manager’ has evolved signicantly over the course of my career with much of our work now focusing on compliance and risk management. We pride ourselves on making sure our clients are well advised, mitigating any risks that may be involved with their particular property.”Some of those clients include retail sites such as Rushmere Shopping Centre in Craigavon.Gail is also one of just eight female surveyors in Northern Ireland with the designation of FRICS, a Fellow Member of RICS.“While females still only make up % of the surveying profession as a whole there are a signicant number of women working within the commercial property sector in Northern Ireland, it’s no longer a male orientated profession.”As for the business landscape Gail says that whilst there is general economic uncertainty they are seeing an increase in demand for their services as investors seek to maximisefrom their investments.“Interestingly we took on a number of new properties over the course of , often on behalf of investors who were keen to maximise rental s and ensure their property is run as efficiently as possible.”  Marian McFlynn, surveyor Since graduating from Ulster University in  with a degree in property investment and development, Marian’s career began on the other side of the globe – working for multi-billion dollar US-owned LaSalle Investment Management at its offices in Sydney.“In Sydney, as part LaSalle’s centre management team, I was responsible for leasing, marketing, administration and operation of a bulky goods shopping centre, home to over  homemaker and lestyle stores,” she says.“I ed to Northern Ireland, and joined the property and asset management department of Osborne King as a graduate surveyor in June ,” she adds. And following training, Marian became a chartered surveyor in . She’s now responsible for managing a range of commercial assets on behalf of clients. “This involves asset enhancement advice, tenant liaison, building maintenance, health and safety management, rent collection and accounting, service contract tendering and service charge administration,” she says.“I continue to build on my client and property portfolio.”And Marian also says that uncertainty hangs in the air for investors, while the ongoing lack of clarity over a post-Brexit landscape still exists.  Lisa McCaffrey, surveyorLisa has five years at Osborne King under her belt. Having graduated from the property investment and development course at Ulster University’s Jordanstown campus in , she worked at a Belfast estate agents before joining Osborne King in  becoming a chartered surveyor in .She works within the professional services team which sees her carry out valuations for a wide range of clients including private iniduals, large companies and the major lending institutions. As part of this Lisa is a member of the RICS Registered Valuers Scheme.Lisa also provides rent review and lease renewal advice to landlords and tenants throughout Northern Ireland.Additionally, Lisa was involved in the  non-domestic rating revaluation providing advice to a wide range of clients and negotiating the valuations with Land  Property Services on the clients behalf at application and appeal stages. Following the  revaluation Osborne King saved clients in excess of £.m. Lisa is working on the upcoming  non-domestic revaluation on behalf of a iety of clients.“I am fortunate to be involved in a wide range of work, some of which involves regular reporting to key clients such as one of Northern Ireland’s largest car showroom operators and well-known supermarket, convenience store businesses and global coffee brand.”  For more information contact Osborne King on   , email property@osborneking or visit the website at www.osbornekingView all articlesSearch ulsterbusiness -- --SearchSearch -- --Follow us -- -- copy  Ulster Business Designed  Built by Laposa, Powered by Onxshop

title: belfast office building comes on to the market
story: Posted on Tuesday  February  by John Mulgrew A major city centre office building with around , sq ft of space has gone on the market. Lighthouse, based at Belfast’s Gasworks, is now available to let. The building includes , sq ft of grade A office accommodation with floor plates of just under , sq ft. The building is being marketed by Osborne King and RHM Commercial. “Given the lack of available grade A office accommodation in Belfast we are excited to bring a building of this size and quality to the market,” Richard McCaig of Osborne King said. “In our experience deliverability of projects is key in order to attract tenants and Lighthouse offers the chance for an occupier to secure the largest amount of existing office space available in the city.” Nick Rose of RHM said it is “extremely rare for an entire building of this quality to become available”. “The superb location combined with a signicant car parking provision will undoubtedly prove attractive to the market. title: kainos taking on bankmore square for belfast office scheme
story: Posted on Tuesday  February  by John Mulgrew Tech firm Kainos will take on a massive proposed office scheme in Belfast for its new headquarters, it has emerged. The firm, which has  global offices but currently has its base off University Street, is taking on a planned , office building at the site of the Dublin Road Movie House cinema. Its understood the company is paying £m for the site. Planning permission has already been awarded for the development but its understood Kainos will submit a revised scheme. Brendan Mooney, Kainos chief executive, said: “Our people remain central to everything we do and we want to ensure that our staff work in the best environment possible, and Bankmore Square allows us the opportunity to create a superb, modern and innovative office for our people. “As well as the additional capacity that the office will bring, this investment, and the location of our new HQ, signals our commitment to retaining and attracting the best staff. We remain focused on providing exceptional careers and working conditions for all at Kainos and hope to close this transaction soon.” Kainos plans to move into Bankmore Square in spring .
